PM

And let's get a few general predictions up

PM

Citi

PM

ECB meeting: Can the ECB overwhelm again? – to overwhelm, we argue that the ECB needs to act on at least three policy levers: i) cut the deposit rate, ii) increase the monthly amount of purchases and iii) adjust its forward guidance, by extending/removing the reference to the Sep-16 guideline. The doves have it, in our view. We believe that the Governing Council will manage to overcome most of its differences and that it will defend its mandate more aggressively to restore its credibility. We look for a 20bp rate cut in the deposit rate, €15bn more of purchases per month from January 16, and an extension of the programme for six months to March 2017. More easing remains likely in 2016, in our view, with more deposit rate cuts in H1-2016 to around -75bp, probably in June.

ECB staff projections: inflation to be revised down, according to newswires – Bloomberg indicated on Wednesday that policy makers has been presented with “updated economic forecasts that are largely unchanged from those published in September”. It quoted one source saying that the ECB will revise down its 2017 inflation forecast to 1.6% from 1.7%.

11:08 am
PM

UBS

PM

We expect a 10bp deposit cut and a 3-6 month extension in the QE programme
It looks like a done deal that the ECB will deliver further easing next week. We expect the ECB to cut the deposit rate by 10bps to -0.3% and extend the QE programme (€60bn per month) by 3-6 months beyond September 2016 while leaving the door open for more accommodation in the future, if needed. We argue that the ECB's menu for further easing is quite rich, with multiple options to adjust the QE programme, shift the interest rate corridor, deliver more credit easing, or try to massage the EUR exchange rate weaker. The ECB might come under pressure to make use of some of these options to try to deliver on fairly high market expectations. 

PM

The delivery of additional stimulus in next week's ECB meeting (3 Dec) to us seems all but certain. The writing has been on the wall since the dovish guidance from ECB President Draghi on 22 October, and reiterated by key ECB policymakers since. The data has actually not been that bad (which explains why our ECB call is more on the conservative side of the consensus): Eurozone PMIs, the German Ifo, and the European Commission's sentiment indicators have held up respectably, while Eurozone Q3 GDP (0.3% q/q, 1.6%y/y) disappointed only slightly.

Yet the renewed decline in oil and commodity prices and its impact on headline inflation (0.1% y/y in October) is having a negative effect on inflation expectations, which could make the ECB's task of bringing inflation back to the target of "close to but below 2%" more difficult. More generally, uncertainty about the economic outlook remains significant, above all given external risks related to China and the EM universe. Against this backdrop, the ECB seems to have concluded that the risk of stimulating too little is bigger than the risk of stimulating too much. Mr Draghi said in October that: "If we conclude that the balance of risks to our medium-term price stability objective is skewed to the downside, we will act by using all the instruments available within our mandate". Executive Board member Peter Praet added: "Uncertainty does not prevent the central bank from taking informed decisions…What is essential is that uncertainty does not give rise to indecision."

With the ECB's decision to deliver further easing in our view essentially a done deal, the importance of the ECB's new macro projections might actually be limited. Its growth forecasts (1.7/1.8% for 2016/17) might be cut only marginally and the inflation forecast (1.1/1.7%) might not come down by a huge margin either (see
Figure 2, below, for the ECB's projections from September).

The ECB has indicated that next week's package might contain a deposit rate cut and changes to the QE programme. Our own expectation is for a deposit rate cut of 10bps to -0.3% and an extension in the QE programme (€60bn per month) by 3-6 months beyond September 2016 – combined with the message that the ECB stands ready to "do more" in the future, if needed.

But we would stress that the ECB's choices for further easing are quite broad, with a rich menu of options from which to choose. As we show in Figure 1, the ECB has multiple ways to adjust its QE programme: shift the interest rate corridor, deliver credit easing, or try to massage the EUR exchange rate weaker.

11:14 am
PM

I see RBC have initiated coverage of Glencore

PM

Tyler Broada

PM

Broda

11:14 am
PM

Tyler's starting position is to sit onthe fence

PM

Glencore has multiple levers to pull. We expect shares to rally on asset sales/further operational improvements, with the 10 December update a potential catalyst. Our detailed analysis suggests that post-asset sales, a credit downgrade to sub-investment grade remains possible, but importantly this should not be a cataclysmic event. Increased cost of equity moderates potential upside on a 12-month view, however. Initiating coverage at Sector Perform.

PM

Wise choice i suspect

11:15 am
PM

Asset sales to lower downgrade thresholds, driving near-term share price improvement - We have analysed a series of divestment possibilities and reviewed specific impacts on credit rating sensitivities. We see potential for Glencore to exceed its asset sales target (upwards of $5bn vs. $2bn target). This, and potential for further operational savings could drive near-term share price performance.
Downgrade remains likely below a $2.00-$2.10/lb copper reference price in 2016 – Glencore is on negative outlook rated BBB/Baa2. On our current assumptions (and after asset sales), should prices remain below a $2.10 level, we would expect a ratings downgrade to below investment grade on 2016 numbers. However Glencore should pass on FY15 numbers. We expect some time before Glencore's rating is downgraded two full notches to below investment grade.
A sub-investment grade rating is manageable in the short-term Although medium-term funding costs would rise, in the absence of significant deterioration in commodity prices, our analysis does not foresee immediate challenges to Glencore's funding related to a ratings downgrade. Glencore's bonds are already trading below a sub-investment grade level. Liquidity of $12.5bn (further helped by potential divestments) should allow Glencore to avoid refinancing pressure until 2017 at the earliest.
Underlying business remains cash generative but $24.5bn net debt level remains albatross for the equity – Glencore's underlying businesses remain cashflow generative (with 2016 FCFY to equity of 2% at spot and 12.5% on our forecasts). Although we expect marketing EBITDA will decline in the current commodity environment, the underlying business remains robust. The quantum of group debt is the challenge. We have run NAV sensitivities at various commodity price environments. Below a sustained $2.30/lb copper reference price, we believe the value of the equity does not offset the debt.
Initiating coverage with a Sector Perform rating, 100p target price. Our price target is based on a 0.7x NAV at a 7.5% discount rate using a medium-term $2.75/lb copper reference price. NAV risking equates to a 10.5% discount rate (elevated financial risks). We remain cautious on a 12-month view on commodity market fundamentals and highlight a $0.20/lb move in reference copper prices moves our spot NPV by ~60p per share.

PM

Valuation:

We have based our 12-month target valuation of 100p based on NPV analysis using a $2.75/lb reference price for commodities and currencies, discounted at a blended 7.5% discount rate (Marketing Division discounted at 6.6% and Industrial Division based on 8% using WACC analysis). We discount our target multiple by 0.7x to account for heightened downside risk from lower commodity prices and higher financial risk than peers.

11:19 am
BE

Morgan Stanley pushing gold miners

BE

FCF of gold producers is at an inflection point. Benefits of improved
capital discipline and declining unit costs have become more visible as most
companies have shifted their focus from producing more ounces to harvesting
returns on existing ounces. This trend has become evident as capital
expenditures continue to decline (6-10% YoY decline across our coverage
universe). We also see a lower risk of returning to the "old ways" (as discussed
in this recent Global Gold Insight Note Global Gold Insight Note) as companies appear to have
changed their behaviour by altering management incentives (increased focus
on returns) and enshrining capital discipline in dividend policies that link
dividend payments either to the gold price or cash generation after
maintenance capex. This reduces the likelihood of capital destruction, in our
view.

BE

Little exposure to China slowdown, benefits from mining-wide cost
deflation. Furthermore, the attraction of gold equities is supported by (1)
lower exposure to Chinese demand as compared to industrial metals, and (2)
margin resilience due to mining-wide cost deflation especially for mines
located in countries with non-USD functional currencies. Our price outlook for
gold remains flat in 2016-17, broadly in-line with current spot, while costs are
set to decline by c. 10% p.a. across our coverage. We should therefore start to
see margin expansion and return improvement across the sector.

11:19 am
BE

Randgold stands out. Within our European coverage, Overweight-rated
Randgold Resources is best positioned to take advantage in this environment.
While acknowledging the valuation premium as compared to other gold
producers, the company has an all-in cash cost estimated fcf yield of greater than on spot in maintains a net cash balance
sheet and is well-positioned to benefit from investment opportunities as they
arise the current environment.>

PM

They've caught me with the intro...

PM

The Big Ten Conference has 14 teams, the Big 12 has 10, Utah's NBA team is the Jazz, LA's is the Lakers. Somehow we can explain these things, but we struggle to explain why people think they can forecast the market multiple, oil, dollar, and rates given so much evidence to the contrary.

11:22 am
PM

This is Adam Parker and team

PM

We joined our macro colleagues around the world in publishing a joint 2016 outlook across the global economy and all asset classes (please see: 2016 Global Strategy Outlook: The Lower Frontier, November 29th, 2015). It is the fruition of an intense, respectfully-contentious, multi-week process from a dedicated, hard-working and extremely talented group of individuals. Importantly, and although we may differ from the group in some of its views, this work is collectively the most cautious the team has been since at least the heart of the European crisis more than four years ago. What do we mean? None of the major strategists is more bullish about their asset classes now than they were over the summer when we completed our collaborative brainstorming for the last "Back to School" process in August (see Global Strategy Autumn Outlook, September 1, 2015). We think this is worth highlighting.
Now a skeptic could say that macro forecasting is difficult, and it is certainly true that not all of the team's macro calls have been successful over the past few years. To be clear, we in US equities live in a glass house, having run the gamut of bearish and correct (2011), bearish and incorrect (2012), bullish and correct (2013, 2014), and bullish and incorrect (2015, unless we get a ripfest in December). So, what's up for 2016?

PM

Lowering 2015 EPS estimates: We were too optimistic about the magnitude of the benefit of lower oil prices and the impact this would have on 2015 earnings. We knew the sharp strengthening of the dollar a year ago and the drop in oil would have a negative impact on earnings for major sectors like energy, industrials, and materials, and that there would be some time before the areas that benefit showed the corresponding upside. However, we had thought that by Q3, the benefits of lower oil would start to lift earnings in other segments of the market. We over-estimated this. While a high percentage of companies were able to show year-over-year margin expansion, the combination of muted revenue and various negatives in industrials, energy, and materials, and less benefits from lower oil in terms of consumer spend and lower input costs, have caused us to reduce our 2015 EPS outlook. We still believe there is upside to the bottom-up consensus outlook, something that has limited precedent since forward earnings data began in 1976.

11:23 am
PM

Our stubbornness stems from the fact that we think our mistake was to under-estimate the length of the lag between the lower oil price and its positive impact in certain market sub-segments, while we continue to believe there is a meaningful benefit. We are lowering our 2015 S&P500 EPS estimate from $124 to $120.5. This is to both mark-to-market for weaker Q3 results and to reduce our estimates for January earnings. The consensus bottom-up number is roughly $119. This means we anticipate earnings growing just over 1% in 2015 year-over-year, not counting a net buyback of about 2.3%.

11:28 am
BE

Themes:

BE

1) Online. The online channel shift is still the most important retail investment dynamic. We look at those retailers affected by store sales cannibalization, more store closures/less openings. We also look at an emerging retail model offering LFL-driven premium sales growth, lower capex/sales and rising ROCE. The performance differential between these will widen sharply as online penetration rises (possibly to c.40% from the current 10%-15%)
2) Forex remains a material gross margin headwind for heavily US$ sourcing, € sales-exposed retailers. We look at the impact of moving toward US$/€ parity.
3) Consumer Demand. We also update our European consumer demand forecasts using Household Disposable Cash Flow analysis.

BE

Upgrades to buy are: Inditex (Conviction List), Next, XXL, Europris

11:28 am
BE

Downgrades to sell are: : H&M, AB Foods, Debenhams

PM

Welcome to Markets Live

BE

And there's a catch-up buy upgrade on Zalando, which happened yesterday.

11:29 am
BE

Here, have the summary.

BE

Online channel is cannibalizing store-based sales and could double from here As European online sales penetration rates rise towards 15%, the precedents provided by the most highly penetrated market (greater than 20% online penetration in the UK) offer useful insight into the future. In the UK, store-based sales cannibalization by the online channel is becoming the norm (Debenhams, M&S), with aggregate space opening slowing to greater than 1% pa and capex/sales ratios fading sharply (from 6% in 1990 to less than 3% today). As such, store closure costs are beginning to impact earnings for those in more mature market positions (Dixons, M&S). In addition, we argue that the performance at Next and focus group feedback from ASOS offer support for the idea that online sales penetration in Europe could more than double from here, to c.40%.

BE

A better multi-channel model is emerging: Capex-light, LFL greater than space growth, ROCE high and rising
Despite this challenging backdrop for the retailers, a strong multi-channel retail growth model is emerging, where online sales growth is largely incremental to store sales, and online sales execution is strong enough to drive an acceleration in LFL sales (LFL greater than space growth), either continuing or accelerating a retailer’s total sales trajectory, despite a fading space growth dynamic. In addition, this model is asset-light (requiring lower capex/sales), driving high and rising ROCE. Good examples are Inditex, Next and Ted Baker. Online aggregators continue to take market share, and EBIT margins are stabilising

11:29 am
BE

The outlook for the pure play online aggregators remains encouraging. Despite more than a decade of rapid growth, the pure play European apparel aggregators continue to rapidly outgrow the online market (2015-16 sales greater than +20% vs online market +c.10%), driven by the virtuous circle of range breadth, price and service driving customer traffic to their sites, driving more brands to their offering, driving customer traffic and so on. Importantly, following a period of heavy and ongoing investment, both Zalando and ASOS’s EBIT margins have stabilized at c.5%.

BE

FX: -150 bp/-250 bp 2016E GM% headwind for H&M/Primark; GS forecasts US$/€0.80 in 2017
The sharp c.20%-25% deterioration in the € against both the US$ and £ over the last 18 months will have a material impact on the sector’s 2016 earnings growth, on both a transactional and translational basis. Transactional forex impact: Here Primark and H&M are the most exposed (c.75% sourcing from Asia, and c.50% of sales in euros), and are facing a c.150 bp and c.250 bp respective bought-in gross margin decline in 2016, on our forecasts which assume current spot. Notably, our economists forecast further €
weakness against the US$ from the current 1.06 to 0.95 by December 2016 and 0.80 by December 2017. In this event, our current EBIT forecasts for H&M and Primark could fall a further c.10% next year and c.15%-20% in 2017/18, assuming this COGS inflation is not passed on to the consumer in higher prices.

BE

Household Discretionary Cash Flow analysis: UK LFL +3%, Spain +2%, Germany +1%, France flat
Household Discretionary Cash Flow (HDC) has the strongest correlation with non-food retail sales trends of any indicator that we have analysed over the last 20 years, and remains a strong consumer demand lead indicator across Europe. Given the high operational gearing of the General Retail sector (c.4:1, EBIT: sales), this revenue forecast analysis makes a strong contribution to our earnings forecast accuracy. The key assumptions driving our HDC forecasts are set out on pages 26-28; however, in summary we conclude that European consumer demand should grow modestly across 2016-17, split UK LFL sales growth +c.3%, followed by Spain +2%, Germany +1% and France flat.

11:30 am
PM

(Frank Underwood -- which blog is it??)

BE

Valuation: We regard sector valuation metrics as reasonable, and sustainable over time
In the UK, both sector EV/EBIT and PE multiples remain in line with the equity market, as has been the case for most of the last 25 years; as such, we argue multiples are both undemanding and sustainable. In continental Europe, valuation multiples are either also in line with historical trends (H&M), or have re-rated in response to either higher growth (ABF) or higher return (Inditex) business models. Our long-run cash flow analysis also supports these current valuation multiples, supporting the idea that they can sustain over time.

PM

(Oh I see it's Winnifrith)

11:33 am
BE

Sorry ... dead air ... just trying to firefight various things going on in the background. Is that enough of this Goldman thing?

BE

Here's the Debs section.

BE

Source of opportunity
As one of the UK general retailers wrestling with the online channel shift dynamic, and in recent times suffering from store-based sales cannibalization, while approaching the end of its UK space growth plans, Debenhams’
earnings growth outlook is modest by European retail standards (c.2% EPS growth over 2016/17 vs. c.10% for peers). In the context of our 83p 12-month target price, we move to a Sell rating on the shares (from Neutral).
Catalyst
The group’s Christmas trading statement in mid-January and the interim results in April 2016 should underpin our earnings forecasts and cautious stance on the shares.
Valuation
We base our 12-month 83p target price on the group holding its current 2016 EV/EBIT multiple out to August
2017. Our TSR is 3%, below the 10% average for the General Retail peers.
Key risks
The key upside risks here relate to more resilient store-based sales (possibly new concession linked), a better-than-expected cost reduction outlook, or an improving UK consumer demand environment despite UK interest rates rise.

BE

InternetQ's share price has been hit hard by investor concerns over weak cash flows. It generated negligible free cash flow in FY14, reflecting working capital outflows (mobile marketing) and rising Capex. There will be disappointment at the extent of downgrades, but if INTQ can demonstrate this is a managed transition of Mobile Marketing into a higher quality cash generative business, we see definite scope for rerating. INTQ is on a FY16F PER of 6.5x and EV/Ebitda of 4.1x, a deep discount to the traditional advertising sector. If we strip out Akazoo (using the external valuation from the Tosca investment), Mobile Marketing is on a 2016 PER of just 1.7x. Our TP is cut from 528p to 385p on the downgrades (still using 8.5x FY16F EV/Ebitda, in line with UK agency peer group average). We stick at BUY, but recognise that sentiment is unlikely to materially improve until it shows improving cash flows coming through from its revised strategy.

11:39 am
BE

Carlsberg likely buyer of Peroni and Grolsch, though Molson Coors might also be interested.

BE

Quick line from Morningstar on the antitrust.

BE

The sale of Grolsch and Peroni should help clear the way
for regulatory approval in the European Union. We have
identified the Netherlands as being the market most likely
to cause antitrust issues, as the two firms hold a combined
30% market share. Grolsch holds a share of around 13% in
the Netherlands, so its disposal should eliminate antitrust
concerns. In Italy, the combined share of the two firms is
around 27%; this is slightly less problematic, but still likely
to raise antitrust concerns. Peroni holds around 25% volume
share.

11:40 am
BE

We believe Peroni and Grolsch represent a material portion
of SABMiller's GBP 4.2 billion annual sales in Europe. At 2
times to 3 times sales, we estimate the divestiture could
fetch $3 billion-$4 billion in cash, which would most likely
be put towards the financing of the SABMiller acquisition.
Despite media speculation to the contrary, Heineken is
probably a nonstarter as an acquisitor of either brand. The
dominant player in its domestic market of the Netherlands,
with a near-40% share through the Heineken, Brand and
Amstel brands, Heineken is also the market leader in Italy,
where it owns Moretti, the country's largest beer brand, and
holds a 30% market share. Carlsberg would have fewer
antitrust barriers to buying the brands, though its 6% market
share in Italy may attract regulator scrutiny. In addition, at
3.4 times debt/EBITDA at the end of 2014, its financial
position is less healthy than that of Heineken, although we
think the balance sheet could sustain an additional $3 billion
in debt. The cost of both brands may be too high for C&C
(not covered), the small-cap Irish brewer of Tennent's and
Bulmers and Magners ciders, although an acquisition of one
of the brands may be possible.

BE

If ever there was any doubt about the true strategy behind
AB InBev's proposed acquisition of SABMiller, we think
these asset disposals, if they occur, remove such doubt. In
order to secure the safe passage of the transaction, AB InBev
has already stated its intention to divest the MillerCoors
joint venture in the United States to Molson Coors. It is likely
to sell SABMiller's stake in the CR Snow joint venture
(Bloomberg is reporting this morning that this process has
already begun), it has sold the international rights to the
Miller brand, and if the most recent media reports are
accurate, it will also sell two of the most popular brands in
continental Europe. It is also possible that antitrust issues
could crop up in other parts of Asia, particularly Australia
and India, and that further asset sales in the region may
follow. What remains of SABMiller is a small European
business (primarily in Eastern Europe) and a strong presence
in Latin America and Africa. We believe it is the latter two
markets that demonstrate the true purpose behind the deals.

BE

Analyst there is Philip Gorham, who's been worth reading throughout this saga.

BE

Macquarie says "close your shorts". They literally do. Valuation call.

BE

 We upgrade the shares to Neutral. There are still considerable risks around
RBS, particularly material outstanding litigation and conduct liabilities that are
virtually unquantifiable.
 However, having underperformed the European bank sector and the UK
market by over 20% year to date (UK banks -12%) the shares are trading at a
c30% discount to European banks (PTBV15e 0.8x v EuroBank average 1.2x).
 For a bank which we believe is pursuing the correct strategy of focusing on its
core valuable UK Retail and Commercial banking franchise (are you listening
Barclays?) this leaves the risks far more balanced. We upgrade to Neutral
and recommend closing the short.

BE

 RBS published a poor set of Q3 results. IFRS PBT £2m was better than
consensus expectations for a loss of £84m. However, this was driven by
lower litigation and conduct charges.
 Core adjusted PBT (ex. US exit and Non-core) £854m was -15% (-£145m)
below estimated consensus.
 Key drivers include weaker than expected revenue including -£126m for IFRS
volatility (weak Commercial Banking and Centrals), and higher than expected
costs (UK Personal & Business Banking and Centrals).

11:51 am
BE

Action and recommendation
 RBS is a challenging bank for investors. Management are good and strategy
correct. Long term there seems little reason why it should not trade at a
similar PTBV15e to Lloyds (1.35x).
 However, before we reach the promised land we need to cross the litigation
desert. RBS is exposed to just about every major sector litigation, plus a few
extra. Trying to quantify these is still fraught with uncertainty.
 That said, we believe that we have provided at the conservative end of the
spectrum (including $10bn for US RMBS action) and still have a 300p price
target. With the risks more balanced we close the short and upgrade the
shares to Neutral.

PM

Barclays has finally managed to close a deal to dispose of (part of) its loss-making Italian retail business. The transaction looks to be at c.0.5x book, i.e. a sale to Mediobanca @ £0.2bn, crystallising a c.£0.2bn loss on disposal. The hit to CET1 capital is c.0.1%. The deal covers 89 retail branches, 600 heads and c.£0.8bn of RWAs (completion Q2 2016), though unfortunately Barclays is still stuck with c.£10bn of low impairment but revenue-negative Italian mortgages. Modest “strategic progress” but hardly transformational.

BE

And this Deutsche morning note, which seems to be getting quoted a lot.

BE

 Ironically, Mario Draghi’s biggest problem is his own credibility. It is
Draghi’s past ability to leapfrog expectations that has itself elevated
expectations to extreme heights.
 Given so many instruments, it is the broader impressions from the press
conference that will ultimately decide whether the ECB has managed to
match or exceed elevated expectations.
 The market needs to come away with the impression that Draghi has the
tools to do ‘whatever it takes’ to lift inflation back to target - a full embrace
of ‘QE whatever it takes’.
 Fears of getting carried away with Draghi’s credibility, coupled with large
scale short EUR pre-positioning explains why the FX market is concerned
about an upside squeeze in EUR/USD. 25 delta risk reversals for the day
on EUR/USD, have been bid for top side to the tune of 4 to 5 vols.
 The one day vols have been consistent with a daily EUR/USD range of
~290 pips, leaving the current downside straddle breakeven very close to
the cycle low at 1.0460 which looks very well protected for now, not least
because the unpredictable US payrolls number comes up so quickly on the
heels of the ECB.
 The US labor market data will answer three big questions: Has the
divergence between manufacturing and the service sector continued in
November? Is the US data weak enough to run with the idea of ‘a dovish
rate hike’? Or, is the market going to have to converge further to the
FOMC dots and add to Fed credibility?
 Even a 150K number in November leaves the 3m NFP average at 186K
which is still a very robust labor market. The probability of a March Fed
rate hike at ~50% looks too low and incompatible with a market expecting
a 200K payroll number.
